bestBHT.bht: Christ commends the widow for giving sacrificially out of her poverty, highlighting that true offering to God is not measured by abundance, but by the extent of our sacrifice. This account not only reveals Jesus' observation of people's giving, but also serves as a reminder for us to give from the heart. Additionally, it signifies Jesus's prophetic warnings about the impending destruction of Jerusalem and his second coming.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Christ's standard of commendable offering is not our superfluity, but our deficiency—not what will never be missed, but what costs us some real sacrifice, and just in proportion to the relative amount of that sacrifice.
As temple offerings are needed still for the service of Christ at home and abroad, so 'looking down' now, as then 'up,' He 'sees' who 'cast in,' and how much.
Christ's prophecy of the destruction of Jerusalem and warnings to prepare for his second coming, suggested by it—his days and nights during his last week.
Marvin Vincent: Offerings of God. The best texts omit of God. Rev., more simply, unto the gifts.
Penury [υστερηματος] . Lit., lack. Rev., neatly, of her want.
Philip Schaff: This incident, witnessed by Jesus at such a time, resembles a flower which He comes upon all at once in the desert of official devotion, the sight and perfume of which make Him leap with joy." (Godet)
Archibald T. Robertson: Constative second aorist active indicative covering the whole crowd except the widow.
Living (βιον). Livelihood as in Mark 12:44, not ζωην, principle of life.
John Gill: For all these have of their abundance... they had large possessions, and gave in much, and yet had a great deal left."
Out of which they cast in unto the offerings of God... the treasury where the gifts, and freewill offerings were put.
But she of her penury hath cast in all the living she had.

bhtAttempts.bht: Christ commends the widow in this verse because she offered out of her poverty, giving sacrificially rather than just giving what wouldn't be missed. Jesus sees not only the amount that people give, but also the heart behind their giving. This passage serves as a reminder to us that our offerings to God should come from a place of sacrifice and devotion, not simply from our abundance. It is also a glimpse into Jesus's perspective on the approaching destruction of Jerusalem and his second coming.

Christ commends the widow for her sacrificial offering from her poverty. He values not the abundance, but the real sacrifice behind our giving. Jesus sees and takes note of those who give to the needs of His ministry and work. This episode is a reminder to us that our offerings ought to reflect our devotion and willingness to make sacrifices for God. Furthermore, it serves as a foreshadowing of Jesus's predictions regarding the destruction of Jerusalem and His second coming.
